What is the output of the following code snippet?


int main() {
    FILE *fp = fopen("sample.txt", "r");
    if (fp != NULL) {
        int ch;
        while ((ch = fgetc(fp)) != EOF) {
            putchar(ch);
        }
        fclose(fp);
    }
    return 0;
}

Consider the following code snippet:


struct Point {
    int x;
    int y;
};

int main() {
    struct Point p1 = {2, 3};
    struct Point p2 = {4, 5};

    p1 = p2;

    printf("%d, %d", p1.x, p1.y);

    return 0;
}

questions.question: In Bayesian networks, what is a conditional probability distribution represented by?
What does the term "overfitting" refer to in machine learning?

options.a: The model performs well on the training data but poorly on unseen data.
options.b: The model performs consistently on both training and testing data.
options.c: The model is too simple to capture complex patterns in the data.
options.d: The model is underfitting the data.

questions.question: What does "underfitting" mean in a machine learning context?

options.a: The model performs well on training data but poorly on new data.
options.b: The model is too complex and learns noise from the training data.
options.c: The model is too simple to capture the underlying data patterns.
options.d: The model is perfect and has zero error.

options.b: By selecting the class of the nearest data point
options.c: By comparing its features to a threshold

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method in Bayesian learning?

options.a: To compute the exact posterior distribution

questions.question: In the context of transactions, what is a "phantom read"?

options.a: Reading uncommitted changes from another transaction
options.b: Reading committed changes from another transaction
options.c: Reading changes only after they are committed
options.d: Reading a range of values that is being concurrently modified by other transactions

options.a: To modify the structure of a table
options.b: To group rows based on a condition
options.c: To perform aggregate calculations on a range of rows
options.d: To drop columns from a table

options.a: To ensure referential integrity between tables
options.b: To limit the number of rows returned by a query
options.c: To ensure that data in a column meets a specified condition
options.d: To create a relationship between primary and foreign keys

questions.question: In the context of database transactions, what does the term "isolation" refer to?

options.a: The separation of transactions from each other
options.b: The ability to roll back a transaction
options.c: The execution of transactions in parallel
options.d: The persistence of data changes after a transaction is committed

questions.question: What is the purpose of the SQL HAVING clause?

options.a: To filter rows based on a condition
options.b: To order the results of the query
options.c: To group data based on a column
options.d: To filter groups based on aggregate values

questions.question: What happens when an attempt is made to instantiate an object of an abstract base class?

options.d: The object is instantiated but throws a warning message.

questions.question: In C++, an abstract base class:

options.b: Must have at least one pure virtual function.
options.c: Cannot be inherited by any derived class.
options.d: Must have all member functions defined.

questions.question: In C++, if a derived class overrides a virtual function of the base class, which keyword is used in the derived class to indicate that the function is being overridden?

What is the output of the following code?
using namespace std;

class Base {
public:
    virtual void print() {
        cout << "Base";
    }
};

class Derived : public Base {
public:
    void print() override {
        cout << "Derived";
    }
};

int main() {
    Base* ptr = new Derived;
    Derived* dptr = dynamic_cast(ptr);
    dptr->print();
    return 0;
}

options.a: Virtual functions must be defined in the base class.
options.b: Virtual functions can be declared as private in the base class.
options.c: Virtual functions are resolved at compile-time.
options.d: Virtual functions cannot be overridden in derived classes.

options.b: If you don't provide a copy constructor, C++ generates a default one.

options.a: They allow efficient insertion and deletion of elements.
options.b: They provide O(1) time complexity for accessing an element by index.

questions.question: Which of the following are true about thrashing in an operating system?

options.b: It leads to high CPU utilization.
options.c: It can be mitigated by increasing the level of multiprogramming.
options.d: It results in low system performance.

options.b: They can be binary or counting.
options.c: They are a type of hardware interrupt.
options.d: They help in avoiding race conditions.

options.b: They can be hardware or software-based.
options.c: They are used to establish a barrier between a trusted and an untrusted network.
options.d: They operate at the Application Layer only.

questions.question: Which of the following are true about VPN (Virtual Private Network)?

options.a: It provides secure access to a private network over the internet.
options.b: It uses tunneling protocols to encrypt data.
options.c: It can provide anonymity by masking the user's IP address.
options.d: It only works with wired networks.
